text: Super hazy, bronzed and copper glow to a two centimetre tall tan head along with a bunch of bubbles rising from the centre of the bottom of the glass. Aroma of rich dry yeast, a lot of bread, some grass, herbs, bananas, flowers and a good dose of light but astringent hops. Medium-bodied; Assertive funky brett flavours with a lot of yeast, some herbs and grass and a very dry oaky and cedar-y flavour with a distinctly dry finish. Aftertaste is nice and floral with the grass, flowers, yeast, oak and dry finishes by far the strongest flavours with some hop bitterness around at all, but there is absolutely no room for sweet, malty or hoppy notes here, this is all about the funky yeast, the dry grain and malt bill and especially the aging in barrels here. Overall, a good beer, especially if its the type of beer you are looking for here. This isnt a great example of this style, since these are typically cookie-cutter-ish, from Belgium, but this is an American-Last Frontier styled nouveaux Belgie, which goes well. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Whole Foods in New York (Columbus Circle), New York on 27-November-2015 for US$11,99 sampled at home in Washington just a few hours after shopping in the same store for more rare-ish beers at WFCC on 11-April-2017.

Bomber from the brewpub. Pours translucent dark gold with a beige head. Aroma of fruit and oak. Med body. Flavor is okay Brett with some white wine aspects. Its moderately sour, very Brett in flavor. Nice flavors.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours cloudy gold with a thick beige head and a white wine aroma. There is a slightly sour medium-bodied pale malt flavor with a lot of oak.

Draught at the brewery. Pours hazy gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is barnyard, earthy, and funky farmhouse yeast, pear esters, earthy hops and citrus notes. Flavor is farmhouse yeast, cellar notes, citrus hops and light bitterness, cracker malt and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Draft at the source. Hazy pale yellow color. Nice aroma of floral haystacks. Taste is perfumy, peppery, floral straw. Tasty.
Bottle: Poured a cloudy orange with white head. Aroma is strong fruit and oak. Taste is huge chardonnay oak barrel, subtle fruit and very spicy tingly peppery finish.

Bottle, 2015 release. Cloudy orange beer, cream colored head faded. Aroma is malt, broiled pineapple. Taste is cloves, orange peal, black pepper, oak tannins. Finish is hoppy astringency almost like an IPA. Its an interesting flavor trip from malt through cloves to hops with a touch of Brett. Palate is light but not thin, carbonation moderate, fine bubbles. Maybe more time in the cellar would increase the complexity.

22 oz bottle at a local gathering from backlog notes. Pours a hazy yellow golden color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor had some base bready malts, oak, chardonnay character, Brett funk, farmhouse, dry, some fruitiness comes through, interesting beer.

Bottle thanks to the true Alaskan action hero Jeff. Pours a cloudy copper color with a medium white head. A funky nose, yeast and light fruit. The flavor is quite nice: light oxidation, funky brett is dominant, medium malt background, Belgian yeast, some deep dry funkiness. Quite good. Has held up well.

Bottle shared at a Portland tasting, thanks for sharing 
Cloudy golden with a medium sized white head and lots of lacing. Aroma of wheat, fruit and dusty. Taste is fruity and slightly tart 
Decent

Rated on 9-25-2009 at Fort Wayne, IN Gathering. This bottled beer is courtesy of jsquire. This beer pours an extremely fizzy white head with a short retention, hazy golden body, one ring of lacing, and visible carbonation. The Aroma is brett, floral hops, fruity, and a hint of spice. The Taste is brett, hoppy and fruity. The Palate is tingly and this beer is medium bodied. All-in-all, this beer is quaffable and worth trying.

[Tap] Tasting notes from mid-September at Humpys in Anchorage. Pours a bright yellow color with a distinct haze to it. Large and lasting white foam head. Funky nose of straw, lemon grass, barnyard and white wine. Dry and winey character throughout. Astringent grains, rose water, Brett, light fruits and grass make an appearance. Not really what I expected, but not too bad. It kind of grew on me actually.
(tap) hazy honey gold colour with small white head; aroma of fruit, stewed fruit; flavour of honey and bit medicinal, long light bitter finish

On tap at the brewery. Pours a clear dark gold color. No head or lacing. Aroma lightly reminds me of wine.  Wine is definitely in the flavor, I find it a little overpowering.  I can taste a little funk from the Brett but for me the wine is just too much.

On tap @ the brewery.  Honey gold clear pour, short lived white head.  Nose is leather and yeasty bread.  Flavor is deep but complex and hard to ID, Brett grabs the front and back, and everything else has to fight to appear.  Well balanced, light on carbonation.

Bottle thanks to someone at Sourfest. Pours with a hazy yellow body with a white head. Aromas of brett, C and Brux by the smell of things. Chardonnay, oak, funky, pear, champagne, light mineral notes. Flavors are oaky, tannic, pear, pineapple, brett c. Medium to light bubbles, tannic and dry finish. Tasty.

Sample from bottle.  Orange pour, slightly hazy, with a white head.  Bready malt, grain, citrusy hops, grass, and a bit of fruit.  Brett yeast character - light funk, tart, and hay.  A nice, drinkable belgian ale, with brett!

Reviewed from notes. Thanks to bmanning.

Poured into my tulip glass. Color is a bright golden with a nice white head and some good ringy lacing. The nose brings wood, grass, citrus, lemon, hay, funk, and some light grain. The taste is quite nice as well. I really enjoy this. A slight fruit presence comes along with citrus and the nice grassy character. A bit of barnyard funk. Really nicely done with a good feel. A bit much in the end and Ive liked some of their other Belgians better, but this is quite good.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010
Bottle...  Poured golden orange with a thick white head.  Bretty nose.  Super dry some hoppiness with a short finish.  A little bit of funk and wood-like tones.  Some grapiness too.

Bottle, thx for sharing tarheels. Pours blonde with a tall fluffy head which leaves good lacing. Aroma is red wine, citrus, rose, and barnyard funk. Flavor is slightly sweet, tart, citrus, tropical fruit but a dry finish. Really nice.

22oz bottle, generously provided by tarheels86. Thanks, GT! Pours a murky, deep orange color; creamy, fine-bubbled off-white head with solid retention and lacing. some acetic character in the nose, along with bright citrus and some lightly funky brett in the nose; some light red wine notes. Medium to medium-full body; lively, fluffy carbonation. Some lightly tannic red wine notes, light aceitc and citric tartness, and a moderate strain of brett; fluffy, lightly tannic, and a nicely shown bret character. Lasting finish of brett and a pleasant red fruitiness; nicely dry.

651mL courtesy of savnac. Well holy god this one was good! The pour is a hazy, glowing, bright orange with a gargantuan ice cream head with infinite retention and stratospheres of lace. Aroma is Brett at its best: fresh citrus, fresh/sweet oranges, rose pedals, spicy oak, fruit caramel, fresh and earthy. Taste is fresh, zippy, dry with sweet fruits, tropicals, mango, caramel, rose, and potpourri. Really just unbelievable. I think the bottle was empty in about three minutes. Need more!

22oz Vintage 2008 Bottle Thanks to ditmier. Pours out a deep gold/orange topped with a off white cream head. Aroma was Brett, fruit,  funk, and some citrus. Taste was Brett from start to finish along with some of the fruit showing up.

From a bomber.  Pour is hazy orange with a large pillowy white head.  Big funky aroma with brett and some tart lemon acidity present as well.  Reminiscent of a gueuze in the aroma.  Flavor starts of slightly spicy, with some earthiness and acidity that lead into dry finish.  Seems a tad dusty in the finish, too.  Thanks JW for this beer.  Pretty damn good stuff.

Bomber shared with mattyb83.  Pours a, deep golden orange with a medium sized fluffy white head.  The brett presence on the nose is so large its almost overwhelming.  Brett, lemon citrus, and barnyard funk comprise the aroma. A high amount of carbonation is present despite only the medium sized head.  A lot of the dry, chardonnay notes come through in the taste.  Yeast, lemon, spice, funk, and slightly acidic for a Belgian ale.  Slight tartness on the finish.  Overall a very nice belgian ale with a big brett funk.
22oz bottle. Rating #76. Clear bright orange with pretty much no head. Big brett aroma, dry and a bit tart. Slight brett in the finish, very drinkable and a bit dry, really nice. (1415)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Brett-y yet quite fruity aroma: dont know that Ive ever had so much of the two in the same beers aroma.  Elegant, slightly dusty flavor - like dusty dried apricots.

Thanks to my FL homie, Jw347, for this surprise in the last box he sent me. You the fn man! Poured into Portsmouth tulip. 

A - Pours a dark yellow/orange, off-white creamy head, nice cap, lots of sticky lacing, and some chucks of goodness from the bottle of the bottle. Very nice looking beer. 

S - Wonderful brett aroma, some oak, melon sweetness (honeydew, cantaloupe). Lots of stuff going on here to meld together and create an awesome-smelling brew. 

T - Brett, slight funk/tart, melon sweetness, oak. Very saison-like, which is a good thing. Very solid. 

M - Light, crisp, refreshing, semi-dry finish. 

D - A wonderful offering from MS. I would love to have this one again and I think theres room for more development in the bottle. Thanks again, JW, for this one. Highly recommend.

A: A gush of beer and foam as the cap is popped, but a quick pour into the glass shows a cloudy golden orange/amber with a huge white head.

S: Tons of brett in the form of an earthy funkiness which is quite pleasing along with the bright, lemony acidity. A bit of oak and grass to keep things nice and "green".

T: The flavor is just as good as I had hoped: a really clean and bright acidity with some lemon and green apple. The funk provides a nice earthy and light bitter note, and some mild oak.

M: The body is toward the light side with a bounty of carbonation that pricks the tongue.

D: One of the best of the Sins beers and even of the Midnight Sun offerings Ive had. Just delicious.

2008 Bottle - Courtest of savnac, thanks!!! - Pours a hazy dk golden with a large, frothy white head...aroma is malty and lemony, straw and dusty funk, typical MS Brett aroma...flavour is pretty straightforward, dusty, bretty vanilla oak, tannic woodiness, raw grain and lemon...
bottle pours gold with a medium white head.  Aroma is honey and floral hops.  Flavor is light grass and hay with a peppery floral hop bite that dry out the finish.

Bomber, courtesy Americanbrew. This one pours a slightly hazy golden yellow body topped by a thick, billowing head of off white foam that shows great retention and eventually leaves sheets of sticky lace behind on the glass. There is quite a bit of carbonation as you can see all the bubbles racing to the top. The aroma shows a decent amount of funk with the brett and old oak up front, and followed by notes of chardonnay grapes, vanilla, and lemon citrus. There is a nice floral hop bitterness in there as well. The flavor follows showing more of the toasted oak and vanilla to balance out the tart lemon citrus, brett, and floral, spicy hops. Sweetness is added by a touch of citrus fruits. The brett really adds a nice funky character to everything though. Medium bodied with lively carbonation and a nice dry finish. This is a really tasty belgian ale with brett.

Bomber at RBWG 2010.  Pours a nice golden with fluffy white head.  Aroma is nice fruity herbal and floral brett- not too horsey or funky- mixes well with light oaky vanilla, light tannin and some chard- hints of lemon lime and just a touch of soapiness.  Flavor is bready doughy malts, mostly clean overall, grassy clean fragrant brett- honeysuckle and honeydew melon, slight honey and sugary syrup- then as it warms there is a brett salt component lemon and lime juice tart hint and a earthy oak char kick at the end.  Good stuff.

Pours a clear orange gold with a big fluffy wheat head.  Nose is soft brett, light chardonay, oak, some light citrus fruits.  A bit sharp on the nose.  Soft pear, apricot like sweetness in the mouth balanced very deftly with a really mild sour lemon quality and mild rolling barnyard tones.  Very soft and balanced, not much spiciness or heat from the oak, which I was worried about.  Not really a huge flavor profile on this but very nicely done.

(22oz bottle)  Pours a lightly hazy golden body with a medium white head.  Aroma of pineapple, nuts, horseblanket, some wet leather, and Belgian yeast.  Flavor of herbs, yeast, earth, brett, and citrus with a dry finish.

RBWG10, courtesy of juiceislose.
pours cloudy golden, light white head.
Aroma and flavors, french oak/wood, light bitetrness, hints of white grapes, grassy mouthfeel, with bretty palate. Wood add this white wine like palate. Nice and slightly sour grape finish.

Thanks to timcd for this one.

A: Pours a slightly cloudy color of gold. Nice tight white head with some spots of lace.

S: Aromas of light summer fruit, citrus, oak, and mild tartness.

T: Nice light Brett flavors. Fruity both sweet and citric. Light notes of grapes and mild oak as well.

M: Medium in body, nice level of tartness from beginning to end.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ bottle pours a white head and cloudy gold color.  Aroma is yeast-brett, medium malt, sour fruit.  Taste is yeast-brett, light malt, sour fruit, some earthy hops.

Bottle thanks to hannont!Particularly rich gold, slightly opaque with a creamy yellow-beige head that laces everywhere. Nose is very reminiscent of 1+ year Temptation, not quite the wood complexity but the chardonnay and brett is nearly spot, light lemon mixing with faint white sweetness. The brett is a mite farther along than desired at this point. The flavor unfortunately loses some of the chardonnay, leaving a near-strictly belgian ale beer with a stronger farm bite and a more apparent hop note, the combination of which is noticeably un-seemless. The carbonation is not quite as soft as Temptation, lightly stinging yet still rather dry. Overall this is a great beer, easily drinkable and yet complex. Its just not at the very top and probably wont get much higher.

I had this quite a while ago; dont know why I never rated it. Had another bottle yesterday. Time to rate!  Colour... semi-cloudy golden-orange with a very thick white head. Nose... redolent of bret, Bret, BRET!! And some grapefruit, too. Palate... loads of CO2 dancing around the palate, plenty of funky bret character, grapefruit, dry, sappy oak, tart, peach pits, and a lengthy finish.

Bottle thanks to savnac.  Pour is hazy deep copper with medium off-white head.  Aroma is floral with notes of white wine and grapes.  Also notes of berries and a faint spruce-like aroma.  Maybe a touch of mint too.  Flavor is very crisp with notes of pepper and tart peach.  Also notes of white wine and light oak.  Its crisp and spicy.

Bottle shared by beernbourbon- thanks homie.   Pours a hazy golden orange with a medium offwhite head.   Aroma of pears, candy, herbal hops, some light brett.  Closest thing to orval ive ever tasted.   Great beer.  I want more!
Thanks to officerfriendly for sharing.  Gold pour with a fluffy egg shell colored top.  Aroma is slightly funky.  Lemon, citrus, grains and cheese.  Another winner from midnight sun!

Bottle. Poured clear yellow color with an average frothy white head that was lasting with good lacing. Moderate brett, wood and yeast aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium sour flavor with a medium sour & sweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met with a change of pace brew.

22oz bottle thanks to bret27.   Hazy orange with a medium white head.   The aroma has plenty of brett straight up front, with lemon, funk, oak, and some honey sweetness.   Overall, pretty rounded in the nose.   The flavor is lightly sweet with some caramel and fruitiness, lightly oaky, spicy, and mildly bretty compared to the aroma, with no tartness.   Hops are mostly mild, but show up a bit in the finish.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation.   Nice oaky component and brett in the aroma, but would probably be even better it it had carried over more into the flavor.

Bottle courtesy bret27. Pours a cloudy orange color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is very bretty, manifesting as cheese and barnyard. Other notes of oak, wine, phenols. Flavor is tart with caramel and lemon, white wine, dough, pepper. Very nice beer in the vein of Orval.

Bottle generously shared by bret27 at a tasting.  Thanks a lot, Bret.  I never thought Id get a chance to try anything from this Deadly Sins series.  Damn it, Midnight Sun, start sending your beer to the Bay Area!  Or else!  Or else...Ill have to keep trying (and usually failing) to trade for it.  Pours a mostly clear golden color with a one-finger white head and great lacing, as Midnight Sun beers tend to have.  Aroma is bretty funk, oak, and sour grapes (like I have for people that have easy access to Midnight Sun beers).  Flavor is bretty and mildly tart with pale malt, oak, sour apple, and dry white wine.  Im told this was aged in chardonnay barrels, but hey, Im a beer guy and I cant tell chardonnay from the next white wine.  Great medium-light palate with mild tartness thats not too mouth-puckering.  Overall a really nice beer, as this brewery tends to put out.
POurs deep orange. Nose is brett, spiced yeast, wood, mild sour grapes. Flavor is dry wood, big funk, bread, grains, mild vinous notes. So so.
strong smell of bread and yeast, but flavor is of stank, non potable water. sorry. Bottle from Ryan Blanksis Sourfest- Hollywood, Florida.

22oz bottle, thanks to kan for sharing. pours murky gold with white head. nose of brett and bread. flavors are very bready, earthy, yeasty, woody, and a tart and sweet bretty finish. this just never came together for me.

50th rating. 2009 bottle. Amber color with a lingering off white head. Awesome bretty cherry, white wine, wet wood aromas with mild earthy barnyard. Frothy light/medium body. Great flavors of barnyard piss, chardonnay, oak, dry hay, with lightly sweet pale malts. Incredible fucking brett brew!  ////////////////2007 batch draft@ Humpys. Hazy golden with a white head. Nice fruity apple lemon cherry pear aromas with mild barnyard. Light/medium body with a smooth mouthfeel. Lightly sweet pear juice, apple flavors with bready pale malts.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: bottle at Ft Wayne tasting from unofficial Midnight Sun ambassador Jsquire - Pours hazy yellow-orange with suspended yeast flakes and a big, bubbly head.  It has a malty, fruity, brett rich aroma.  It has a fairly light, fruity flavor with mild hops and some brett apparent.  The body is a little thin.  Theres mild bitterness in the dry finish.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2009 22oz bottle from Todd. Thanks again... Pours a semi-opaque medium orange brown with a medium frothy white head... Some farmhouse and dirty Brett notes with tropical fruit and tangerine scents... Flavors are mainly sweet tropical fruit with drier Brett notes in the finish. Semi-earthiness comes through eventually.  Little wine barrel nite bit good degree of Brett. Nice mouthfeel.

Bottle. Rich amber beer with a cream colored head. Tart, lemon, green apple aroma with light yeastiness. Tart, lemon, yeast, and light spice flavor. Medium bodied. Yeast, spice, green apple lingers with light malt and a light tartness.
pre-GABF. Great Brett scent. Strong woody Brett flavour. Really connects!!

22 oz bottle.  Foggy orange brown with a puffy white head that leaves lacy swirls and spots.  Nose is banana, yeast, honeydew and white pepper.  Medium body with zingy carb.  Taste is honey, grass and sourdough with herbal notes and lemon peel.  Just a touch of funk.

Pride reminds me of a Jolly Pumpkin beer, mostly in the yeast.  Thin, rocky head. Gold colored and very heavily carbonated. Wild yeast, with wheat, grapefruit, and some grain.  Some sweetness.  Good palate, with carbonation on the tongue.
Bottle shared at Logans pre-GABF party.  Pale yellow pour.  Aroma of lemon, funk, and mild brett tartness.  Excellent tart flavor; mildly funky.  A great beer.

WTWBA MPLS 2009.  Brett dominated the lightly malty aroma of this wonderfully fizzy golden colored beer.  A little vinous character in the body from the barrels, but not much.  A delightful beer that reminded me more of a saison than a belgian strong.

This bottled brew from JSquire at a rating party poured a extremely large sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were and left behind a transparent strongly carbonated light orange colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was astringent and malt hop. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of malt astringent and soft floral hops . A decent one but not one that I would consider drinking again.

Unretired?

Appearance:  Pours a cloudy dark gold with a small ring of white froth for head.

Aroma:  Fruity and funky brettanomyces, lending aromas of green pear, rain water, rust, and light barnyardy odor. The malts are there in the nose, but take a back seat to the buggy yeast.

Taste:  Fruity yeast, followed by some industrial metallic notes, spicy bitter hops, and an ever so slight note of oak, but almost unnoticable.

Mouthfeel: Decently carbonated, and rather dry in the finish.

Overall:  A really nice beer. I dont always enjoy a beer with brett, but this one was really good.
Pours a hazy golden color. Small off white head. Brett aroma with other earthy bready notes. Taste of sweet pale malts, slightly earthy hops and brett characters.

22oz bottle. Slightly cloudy golden with a thick foamy white head that lasts a long time and leaves a big ring of lace. Big Brett aroma hits you right away, followed by oak, spicy yeast and a slight citrus character. Flavor is mostly sour with a mild sweet malt base and a touch of bitterness. Medium body with active carbonation and a long dry finish. Wow, the Brett has really come out in this one, very funky and very good.

Another rare beauty pulled out of his cellar by JW77.  Damn!    Hazy gold/yellow pour.  Big head.   Crazy funky aroma.  Wood, vanilla, golden raisins, brett and sourness.  Flavor is dry and funky.  Some lemony notes lead to old oaky flavors.  Unique and very interesting beer.
Bottle thanks to suzygreenberg. Thanks Ben. Very enjoyable belgian ale. Nice crisp flavors of pepper, spice, clove, lemon peel. Very good.

650 ml bottle at Toncatcher’s house, shared with Padrefan, Fordest and a few others. Cloudy yellow pour with lots of floaties, thin white head. Nose of brett, oak and sour grapes. Taste is overtly sour with grapes, sweet apricot, persimmons and some wood. The finish is long and dry. The mouthfeel is full and malty. Overall: A very nice complex sour beer.

Bomber.  An absolutely massive, billowing head of thick, spongy foam lasts for eons, slowly creeping of the edge of the glass, letting you know right off the bat something really funky is going on here.  Eventually, solid sheets of ultra-sticky foam are left behind to slowly break apart into tattered ribbons.  The underlying body is golden in hue and very lightly hazy, with intense streams of micro-bubble effervescense screeching towards the surface.  The nose is funky as can be, very bretty and old-oaky, with alot of toasted wood and vanilla character.  Light golden fruits lend little sweetness, while lemony citrus esters and staunch floral hops serve up the counterpoint.  The flavor isnt quite as funked out.  The brett presence subsides just a little, leaving funky toasted oak notes, dusty floral hops, pepper and citrus rind.  The farmhouse character is very Orval-like, though not quite as magical.  Medium-plus on the palate and semi-dry, the carbonation is lively but fine, and not nearly as prickly as I thought it might be.  Overall, this is a damn fine representation of a bretty Belgian pale.  Good stuff.

Interesting nose of oak and funk. Opaque orange golden pour with a nice bubbly head. Nice spicy sweetness initially followed by a barage of funky bretty notes and a light lemon note. Lingering dryness from the oak.  Big carbonated bite, maybe too much for me.

Bottled.  Awesome beer!  Nose is just wonderful...pleasant oak, brett, grassy.  Picked up a nice citrus (lime) along with all the dry, biscuity, brettiness that makes this small pale just a great beer.  Gets a load of character from the wine barrel too, which I liked.  I wish I had more of this around for when I wasnt in my typical, big brew mood.

22oz bottle. Pineapple brett with a hint of wood tannin initially on the nose. The yeast esters present themselves as dried fruit skin. Peaches and apricots. Quite dry and grassy. Very floral and aromatic hops with a decent pale malt base. A very pleasant and inviting aroma. Pours Dark, cloudy orange with a thick white head leaving drippy lacing down the sides of my glass. Flavor is crisp and quite refreshing. Dry, pale malt. Snappy, grassy and slightly spicy hops. Just the smallest hint of tannic wood on the back end. Really reminiscent of a Jolly Pumpkin brew. A good amount of brett throughout, but far from overpowering. Medium to full bodied for the style. Lively and mouth coating carbonation. Insanely drinkable. I would drink the hell out of this if it was available locally to me. Thanks Tim!

Pride is #6 on my list of the 7 Deadly Sins brews, courtesy of NoonanDBarbarian.  Poured into a tulip.

Pours a slightly hazy golden orange with a massive bubbly white head that shows great retention and sheets of lacing.  Streams of carbonation come up from the bottom to feed the head throughout.  It certainly looks tasty.

The aroma has lots of fruity sweetness with apricots and apples on top of a hint of Belgian yeast and some spicy notes.  There is a noticeable funk in the nose as well, but certainly nothing overpowering.

The taste starts with just a touch of hop kick before giving way to the Belgian yeast and light fruits.  The funk is much more subtle in the taste and is only slightly detectable in the finish.

The mouthfeel is light to medium and very, very smooth for a Belgian pale.  Probably a little thin for the style but makes it very easy to drink.

Due to the fairly low ABV, the drinkability is high on this one.  It’s a good brew, but one that is probably on the lighter side of things as Belgian style ales go.
Thanks to bitbucket tasting. Tons of carb. Fairly clear golden. Mix of light funk and some earthiness. Odd taste of anise seems out of place. Enjoyed, but kind of odd.
UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 22 oz. bottle. Firm white head, hazy golden color, spicey apple aroma. The bretts give a light funk to an outstanding strong ale.Nice subtle fruit, an excellent beer.
22. Thanks again, Derkruk! Pours cloudy gold with a lacy white head. There is a sour, funky, sweaty aroma, and a surprisingly sweet taste of fruit and funk with a lemony finish.

22 oz. bottle - slight foam over after opening; pours deep gold with low carbonation and huge white head thick enough to eat with a spoon; lots of lacing; aromas of lemon zest; apples and spice; mouthful of strong flavors and quite sour; strong zing too it and not quite in balance overall

clear amber pour, with huge fluffy white head.  strong aroma of sweet fruit and citruis.  flavor is weak compared to the aroma, theres not really any sweetness and it comes across a little over carbonated and dry.

Golden honey in color. Healthy dollop of meringuelike foam adorns the glass with abundant lace. Extravagant and uplifting nose of white pepper, lime sherbet, honeydew melon, flowery hops, unripe peaches, Band-Aid and faint vanillin. Delightfully perfumey with a mild scent of crackery malt. Expansive carbonation condenses into a fine cream as it graces the palate. Initially briskly dry with a palate-scrubbing snap of peppy white pepper and plasticlike phenols. Band-Aid accentuates the already beautifully snappiness as succulent floral underpinnings enhance the lustrous esters and soften the body. Remarkably bright and quaffable with a well-rounded twinge of tartness. Pils malt is simplistic and artfully restrained, yet multidimensional and soundly structured at the same time as it reveals suggestive notes of crackers and fresh hay. Some caramelized-nut richness also develops as the beer reaches room temperature. Juicy yet subtle hoppiness fuses with the estery tropical fruitiness which is gently offset by the well-defined vanillin- and coconut-tinged oakiness. Dazzling interplay between the dryness and succulence as the beer is immaculately attenuated. Tight minerals, Band-Aid phenols and whispers of oak offset the slick fruitiness as they gently grip the palate. Finishes vibrantly flowery with grassy-hop accents amid a lingering fusion of crisp malt and creamy yeast. Lots of finesse and subtlety are on display here. Hats off to the brewers at Midnight Sun for yet another fine Belgian-style ale.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
Appearance: Pours a clear, orangey, effervescent body with a pillowy, white head.

Smell: Vaguely malty aroma with notes of oak, flowers, lemon, and that unmistakable Brett character.

Taste: Delicate, light maltiness for the oak and chardonnay to ride out on. Fairly floral and with a spritz of tropical fruit juices. Never much sweetness present. One lemon seed. Light spice. Incredibly light, earthy funk. Finishes rather dry.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Full, lively carbonation, baby!

Drinkability: A tasty beer and that even a sourpuss like me could freely enjoy.

A dark golden color with a large frothy head. The aroma is yeasty with the brett showing as well as some citrus and vinegar. The flavor is sour but not over done. I taste a good deal of funk and light citrus flavors. The mouthfeel is carbonated. Overall another winner from this brewery!

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2009 
Date: May 24, 2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: clear gold. big frothy off white head, streaks of drippy lace
Aroma: sweet malt aroma with lots of winey sweetness and a spicy sweaty character
Flavor: dry malt flavor, lots of spicyness, touch of wine character, earthy musky funk, light bitterness

Date: August 29, 2009
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar tasting
Vintage: 2009
Score: 3.2 to 3.4
earthy brett funk is coming through a lot nicer on this batch, less of the winey sweetness, 

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Pours a transparent golden bronze with a fully-lacing froth of white head.  Aroma of lightly sweet biscuity pale Belgian malts with a touch of floral grassy hops and leathery complexity.  Starts with a semi-sweet biscuity malty sweetness balanced with a drier earthy grassy character before a mildly funky, drier finish.  An authentic and enjoyable bretty brew.
Pours a copper color with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is brett, fruity, funky, oak, and some peppery hops.  Flavor is brett, funk, oak, vanilla, and a peppery hop finish.

The aroma is wonderful in this beer, with some sour woody notes, wet hay and a hint of vanilla and  sour citrus.  Light fruit undertones and a bit of earthiness, herbal hoppiness and some chewy maltiness, I dont think the brett has really had a chance to grab this beer, will try it again in a few months.
Peachy colour.  Nice head. Soft carbonation.  Wonderful vinous aroma, woody and with light brett.  Tart, woody, with great pear-like fruitiness.  Dry finish.  Nice brew.

Many thanks to puzzl for sharing - hazy straw color, with a sticky lace - very herbal and minty aroma, with a spicy bite to it - quite dry, with some apparent phenolic flavor - some pale, biscuity malt, but it is mostly dry - light brett and some oak - herbs and grain - a wee bit of citrus fruitiness - pretty nice, but Id like to try it once the brett has taken stronger hold.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008  Draught  Very high, collapsing head over orange beer. Very fruity nose with orange peel and strawberry flavour; some fine spices, as laurel, but smelling already a bit "hot" in fermenting. Fruity with a bitter finish. Little mineral saltiness. Noble hops, not USA, some orange peel again. Cant get the Bretts. Medium bodied, but very slick, a bit oily. Yes. Another Wh/y/labs/east offshoot. Still, it shows some character.

Thanks to puzzl for sharing this one.  Deep straw colour.  Aroma is quite rich and peppery with a lovely spiciness and a sweet honeyish character as well.  Herbal and quite fruity on the nose.  A bit of raspberry and bubble gum.  Flavour is lightly earthy and a little bit dry as well.  Warming brings up some ginger and melon... it needs a bit of time for the brett to come up, but even now, this is damn tasty.

Shared by puzzl, nice one. The beer pours a thick golden color with a strong but small head.  Its very pretty looking, cannot see through the beer, its a bit of a muted gold, not shiny, color. Its a very nice nuanced beer.  Aroma is at first herbal, which I first though as "blah" but as I stayed with the beer other interesting aspects came out.  I got a light brett, in the way of light dry pineapple. It worked nicely with the herbal yeasty character.  Taste is again herbal but not as strong.  It left a dry and lightly sweet aftertaste. It reminded me a bit of some Orval bottles I have come across. I would really like to see how one of these is doing with some time on it.22oz bomber, Rodenbach GC smaller tulip.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle. Very dry aroma, a good bit of bitter melon, perfume. A little oak in the flavor, vanilla. Super dry, with horsey brett. Rather than being acidic this tastes very basic. An interesting experiment.

22oz from AKBelgianBeast on the other site. Thanks, Frank! Big, big golden pour with a very large, quickly expanding head. Awesomely funky aroma, like a fine saison with traces of oak and musty brett. The base beer is a nice golden Belgian, like Witkap Pater perhaps. But the super dry finish and dank qualities give it a nice complexity, particularly for those that enjoy such dirty funky brews. Not on par with Russian River in this general area, but a very fine effort.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 Golden color with a foamy white head.  The nose has that funky Brett that I am starting to not find offensive with sour lime and horse blanket notes.  The taste has the classic Brett funk with old citrus rinds and moldy straw.  I am starting to distinguish between the sour, which I dont like, and the Brett, which I am beginning to enjoy.  Im going to have to redrink many Brett beers to see if my other ratings will increase.
22oz bottle shared courtesy of TomDecapolis (thanks!). Aromas of citrus, brett, leather, and wood / oak. Tastes of brett, ligher citrus, wood, vanilla, and some spiciness. Lively body.

Poured a lightly hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett brux, toffee, toasted dough, wood, and light citrus.  Taste of more vanilla, toffee malts, light toast, citrus, white pepper, wood, and a dry, light bretty finish.  Thanks Tom!

Pours a lightly hazy golden amber with a large foamy/bubbly white head that left spotty lacing.  Aroma was woody, very floral, citrus notes, tropical fruits, peppery notes, cantaloupe, bready, light barnyard/bretty notes.  Flavor of hops, earthy notes, tropical fruits, chardonnay, oaky, brett is there but not over the top, some mettallic notes, tea and a touch of hop bitterness and dry.

Poured a hazy golden color with a white head.  Citrusy aroma with a moderately bretty yeast note.  Almost a chardonnay aroma but wiothout the wine smell if that makes sense.  Nice Bretty flavor and bitterness mixing with the fruity citrus flavors.  Lively carbonation.  Dry finish bordering on the "too dry for me" dryness.

Pours hazy gold, with an inch-plus head of white fluff.
Lacework aplenty as the brew sips down.
Aromatics are all about the brett. 
Cloves, dusty boards, dried pineapple, lemon oil, juniper berries, wet hay, and bitter greens.
The mouthfeel is light, super-dry and crisp. Very refreshing.
The pallet has a light malt base, with tropical citrus notes, bitter fruit pith, and a mild funkiness.
Hopping is heavy handed in the bitterness, moderate in the middle, and the grassy overtones hint at some dry-hopping as well.
Finishes bone-dry and firmly bitter, with lingering phenolics.

The French oak aging really doesnt add any oaky tones, but Im sure it helped dry out the beer along with the Brett.

A terrific ode to Orval, and markedly better than the Matildas Ive had in the past.

Golden pour with frothy thick head.  Nose has hints of spice, fruit and light hops.  Flavor is tangy, herb, spice and a touch of wood.  So many flavors, its really hard to pull them all out.  Medium body that leads to almost a mushroom covered in dirt. I will say that it is almost lacking in the finish.  Just kind of quits towards the end.

Draft glass at Cafe Amsterdam.  Metallic orange with a boiling and firm top.  The aroma is light and spicy.  The beer drinks with a moderate herbiness, corriander and some other earthy tones.  The undertow is fruity and malty.  Nice.  (#3301, 1/20/2008)

Sunny blonde pour; silky white cream with a lasting thickness.  Cool cucumber vinaigrette, dill and clove in a very dry and lightly pungent aroma; minerals, banana, dark biscuits, a hint of lime zest.  Not especially bold with tangy funk quite yet, but pleasantly spiced and showing a sophisticated brisk character.  Flavor is tepid and underdeveloped, like something designed to highlight the strange nuances of brett but that has been disturbed too quickly.  Lovely mineral and tart citrus flavors lean uneasily into a sharp metallic glint that softens slowly but never quite concedes; the chardonnay barrel lends a soft buttery warmth of coconut, toasty oak and vanilla.  Hollows out with iron and aluminum toward the end; strongly effervescent, very soft and medium bodied in the mouth, finishing with a taste of fluffy white dough and an empty drying sensation longing for the forceful, rich pulse of brett.  Regretfully, this bottle should have aged quite a bit longer, but the impression it leaves, even while quite young and rough edged, is definitely still pleasant.  Thanks Tim!

22. Thanks, Kim! Murky dark amber with light gray fizzy filmy head. Sharp poopy nose with some light sour vinegary tang. Medium fizzy body. Light mineraly fizzy mid-palate. Somewhat sweet vanilla (oak) note emerges near the finish.
